128767337.review:
My husband and I were searching for a good co-op (actually co-op - not competing against each other, and not something that was combat-based), and I'm deeply deeply into puzzle games. We found that this one was on the cheaper side and rated very well, so decided to give it a try. We both loved it.

The story was outstanding. There were no jump-scares per say, but the atmosphere was definitely creepy and at some points I was a little freaked out, which I loved. The puzzles were absolutely 10/10 amazing for co-op, nothing ever got frustrating, and it just worked really well the way it's all laid out and designed. Absolutely worth the money and we WILL be playing it again with me in the other role/with the other insect, possibly doing it 2x more for all achievements. Absolutely outstanding and we both hope to see more co-op puzzle games like this from this developer.

If you want a sort of comparison, it's a TINY bit like a simplified version of Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes, but without a time limit/inherent danger. There is one timed puzzle but it's not that difficult and if you fail, you just start over. As far as we could tell, nothing can stop your progression permanently. It was super fun and engaging to communicate and have dual Eureka moments. Can't wait to run through it again!

124918928.review:
I really like the rusty lake series and I played each game multiple times. I had to say that I am a little disappointed with this one. 
Pros:
1. Sound design is awesome as always. I preferred music from the white door but this one is still great. 
2. The environment is doing its job perfectly. I really got spooked a few times. 
3. The 3D part is pretty cool and also new experience for old rusty lake players. 
4. I had fun with my partner. I like that we need to communicate to solve puzzles.
5. My partner has never played rusty lake series and he did enjoyed the game and won't complain about it. 

Mixed: The multi player part isn't synced or connected which I don't really care. It's not a priority for me at least. It's just a bit confusing when the game tell both of you to do something at exactly the same time. 

Cons:
1. The play time is really short even compared with other rusty lake games. I finished the game with my partner for about one hour (butterfly mode). We bought the game for a 40% discount so 3.5$ each so I won't complain too much. However, if I bought this at full price, I'd feel a bit more disappointed. 

2. The play time would be fine with me if there are more puzzles and story elements in the game. On the contrary, the puzzles are quite simple. Most of the story we already know from past games. Maybe I missed some lore but I feel like there isn't much to say about the story. 

3. Some of the puzzles are simply redundant. There are multiple puzzles that are just letting you repeat the same instruction times and times again, which isn't really fun. It can be a little frustrating. 

4. There's not much point in trying both modes to be honest. Both butterfly and bee has same puzzles only, of course, you get a bee or a butterfly model. The answers may change sequence but it's really the same thing. My partner and I finished both mode in 2 hours. 

5. The 3D part is cool but I have to be honest, I'm not that impressed. Different games (the room for example) have done similar things before. It's not bad but it's not impressive enough to let me ignore the previous points. 

Overall, I don't think I would recommend this game to a new player at this moment. My partner didn't complain about it and think it's okay. But he did say he probably wouldn't buy this if I didn't want to play it (I gifted him one). If you really really do love the rusty lake lore and want to dive deep into the details, sure this game isn't that bad. I just think there are too few features that attract new players or returning players who love puzzles and would like to know how the story develops. I also wouldn't recommend buying this one at full price. Two or three dollars for me is more acceptable than 6 dollars. I have to say I'm a bit disappointed and I did expected more from the rusty lake series.

133383190.review:
The past and future collide.

Story:

You play as two characters, one of them being Rose Vanderboom. One of you is in the past and the other in the future and your father Albert has left instructions on how to make a connection between two different years and another sinister instruction and so you set out to make his wish into a reality. 

The story is very minimal in The Past Within, there's definitely a little bit more added lore to the Rusty Lake series. but this time around it's a lot more gameplay focused. I did like what's here, there's some genuinely good story advancements and I'm really excited to see where the next game in the series will go next.

Graphics:

Visually The Past Within also tries something new just like The White Door did and this time around Rusty Lake goes 3D. There's still the same 2D segments designed the same way they were in in the other games in the series. And generally the style is just as good as it ever was, however this time around it's a little less surreal.

The 3D environments however are amazing. I genuinely loved how great the world of Rusty Lake translated into 3D and seeing some of the visuals that you kept looking at throughout the franchise in fluid 3D was quite the trip and I definitely loved how the unique atmosphere each side gets. 

Audio:

The audio design is generally pretty good and the issues of the franchise like audio crunch has gone away with this entry. There's some decent background music that's not intrusive when trying to communicate with your partner. It's actually very nice and does add to the creepy atmosphere even further.

There's some other sound effects, but generally they're either taken from the other games or so minor that they're not really worth talking about. It's made to be as less annoying on the ears as possible to make it easier to communicate which is nice, but when do you hear sound effects they're pretty decent.

Gameplay:

In the past, the Rusty Lake games were single player experiences where you solved puzzles all by your lonesome, however this time around you're bringing a friend into the nightmarish world of the Lake to help you out with the puzzles. There's still the standard type of puzzles you'll have to solve yourself, but a lot of the game is designed to be tackled with a partner. 

So let's begin with the puzzles. Rusty Lake games have often been very complex and had their surreal nature bleed into it. The Past Within puzzles are a lot more streamlined and much more simple than anything the franchise ever had. This was probably done to make it much easier to describe to player and honestly while the puzzles were much easier, they were still a great time.

The puzzles themselves are probably the biggest negative the game has about it. It's pretty easy overall as you pick up what you need to do almost straight away with only a few puzzles having a stump in difficulty and even then the solution for them is basically a massive hint, you just need to find where to use it.

Also it's quite great that this game technically can be played up to 4 times per side as there's two different puzzle settings and then the past and the future which amounts to a decent amount of play value with a single playthrough taking up to 2 hours, so you can really maximize how much you and your friend get out of the title.

Also quite a lot of the jank the series used to have is also gone and is a lot more refined. I really hope that the series uses this engine going forward as this generally felt like the most fluid Rusty Lake game to date and I really liked more advanced gameplay. 

Verdict:

The Past Within is a great addition to the Rusty Lake series and a brilliant co-op experience if you and your friend likes puzzle games. While it's a bit too easy than the other games in the series and has some weak design choices, it's yet another worthy trip to the Lake. 

Final Rating:
9/10

Pros:
+ Visuals are a mix of old and new and mesh very well
+ Some really fun puzzles
+ Story has some interesting developments to the lore 
+ Audio design is great and doesn't intrude when solving puzzles

Cons:
- A lot of the puzzles are too easy 

If you liked this review please consider joining https://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog and https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews

125117149.review:
As this is Rusty Lake's first co-op entry, the puzzles are understandably less complex. Instead, the focus of the game is on communicating the various symbols and codes your partner will need to solve their puzzles and vice versa. Only one sequence in the 1 to 2 hour affair uses a timer to up the stress of trying to translate an input and, while it is fail-able, it is also infinitely repeatable. So don't worry about having to find someone you have a near psychic link with before getting started, fumbling is part of the experience. 

Despite being a bit shorter than a Rusty Lake title and more on par with one of the studio's earlier Cube Escape games, you'll probably want to play through The Past Within at least twice. Once to see things from the Past's perspective and another from the Future's. Thankfully, there's an alternate puzzle solution mode to avoid memorizing to much too quickly and cheating yourself out of the full deductive process.

The same should be said about deciding to play the game alone. Considering its nature, it does seem possible to get through it without a partner(I think there's already a guide to just that effect), but most of the fun and the intended course of the story depend on indulging in the difficult task of trying to reach out to someone similar but still very outside of yourself. Take that away and you're only getting half of what The Past Within has to offer.

Good game. Not better than the best games in the series, but not worse than the others. It really is a spin-off about Albert and Rose, which adds to the fullness of the universe. As a fan of Albert, his story, and his two women, I enjoyed this game.

What I didn't like was a lot of monotonous "look and tell me what you've got" puzzles. There was some variety, like the speed riddle and the old-school "make coffee, make the right piece of meat" type of riddles. I wish there was more variety.

The parts of the game where you act as coordinator are the most boring. While your friend walks around the room, you sit and just spin the box. The developers try to innovate the gameplay of each game, and more often than not it has been successful (RL Roots, Paradise, The White Door,) but this time not so much.

My friend had a bug on the speed puzzle, and we couldn't finish the game. In the end, I finished it myself. We finished game in another mode.

The initial menu is a little annoying instructions that you can not skip and "are you sure your friend joined". It's also a shame that there is no controller support.

Overall, I think the game is overpriced. However, it is worth taking into account that this is an independent group of developers.

What I liked about the game is the good old Rusty Lake atmosphere, the gorgeous Albert, the story is good. The familiar elements of the game are well done. But I would like more gameplay and more interesting puzzles. Maybe more history of Albert and Rose.

In the meantime, I'm looking forward to the next game!

A co-op experiment from Rusty Lake. Always solid art (and 3D for the first time!) and sound effects. However, the puzzles are way simpler than any other titles from Rusty Lake.

This title is a spin-off so no need to have previous experience with the Rusty Lake franchise, although it is desirable to play Rusty Lake: Roots first to better grasp the (very light) story.

The Past Within is also a co-op only experience. However, you can also open two windows at the same time and play it alone. Two players have asymmetrical roles and views. So after your first playthrough, which will last around 1 or 2 hours, you may want to play a second time in another role.

All in all, I recommend this title, even for newcomers to Rusty Lake or fans who only want solo gameplay. I also suggest trying the demo first, which is a short (around 15 minutes) but faithful and independent demonstration of the full game.

134899830.review:
This game doesn't have a single puzzle in it.

The gameplay loop consists of:

1. Searching around like a madman for inputs/outputs that sync up with your partner's.
2. Repeating step-by-step basic instructions to your partner or receiving instructions and doing exactly what your partner/the game tells you to do.
3. Repeat for 2 hours

Also, you might want to consider reducing how much you make the players repeat tasks. There's a reason why, in most games, players are tested on new concepts simultaneously with ramping difficulty or complexity until they master it and can integrate it into other game elements.

This game does no such thing. Instead, you're made to repeat chores with your partner over and over again with little variation or challenge. The "challenge" lies in the fact that you cannot see your partner's screen.

For example, there's a chore where you read clock hands to your partner and they set a clock accordingly on their end. I know how to set a clock, so it wasn't even fun the first time. Why then, game, do you make us do it like eight goddamn times? WE ALREADY MASTERED THE ART OF SETTING CLOCKS, GAME.

There are many other small tasks that players are made to repeat many times, such as the XYZ puzzles or the dials with symbols on them. This is genuinely upsetting and shows a lack of respect for the player's time. Many tasks are repeated over and over again, and not a single one of them constitutes a puzzle or requires critical thinking.

It almost feels like padding to exceed the refund window. And bravo, you got me, game. I am aware it's only $6, but it feels like I am owed money for playing this to the end.

Arguably, the most critical thinking you'll use in this game is filtering what information is relevant to your partner. However, this mostly devolves into a brute force approach where we just rattle off everything we see, and it quickly becomes annoying.

The initial premise was interesting, and the atmosphere enhanced it, but next to nothing was done with it in this work, leaving a hollow shell of nothing happening. I understand there's a narrative that's expanded upon in your other works that is probably terribly interesting, but if it means playing more games like this, I'll have to pass.

That being said, I would be unfair not to say that my partner really enjoyed it and wants to do another playthrough. Maybe it's simply not to my taste, but this is not a game I ever want to play again.

Anyway. This was a novelty and the 2-player stuff was innovative, so, thanks for making it. I just wish somebody had warned me.

125218903.review:
[h2]At Last[/h2]
The Past Within is here, and it's going to feel different from other entries in the series, mainly for the cooperative mode. If you want to dive in without any further knowledge, well... I'll say that it's a interesting experience and you'll have a great time.

If you want to hear more, here are some top of mind pieces of feedback.

If you want to see more indie games, many of which I've reviewed, please check out my youtube channel. 
Link [url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXMd490dpLAJxONpEpvOMnw] here [/url] and after my closing thoughts!

[h3]Addressing Co-Op[/h3]
It's safe to assume that many wondered if The Past Within would retain that classic, Rusty Lake feeling while at the same time being cooperative in nature. 

Rest assured, it does. 

Everything screams Rusty Lake as usual, and the atmosphere is more pronounced here than it was in The White Door, which in and on itself was still a great experience, even if different. Being cooperative isn't necessarily the way to go for this series, but it's been around for so long and with so many titles that this feels like an exciting, fresh experience on top of already successful and interesting games.

With that said, cooperation comes at a cost: complexity. While The White Door was certainly different from the more classic feel of The Past Within, I'm afraid the latter did sacrifice much of its complexity in order to mantain the cooperative structure. 
That's perfectly fine and I can see why they went this route, since your friend/partner/whatever may not be used to play Rusty Lake at all and could have an odd time figuring things out. That has been my personal experience, at least. 

Being used to the common puzzle structure amongst the series, I've found a gap between me and my partner in how puzzles are approached. With that said, I still think that going the easy route with its estimated 2 hour length may have hurt longevity a little.

Given how much it costs, though, there's no reason to be mad about it or anything like that. 
It's just my personal consideration, and I've enjoyed everything it had to offer and its cooperative structure more than I expected!

[h3]The Past Is In The Future[/h3]
To my knowledge, this is the first 3D Rusty Lake game. And they absolutely nailed it. Actually, you'll have a mix of 2D and 3D based on which timeline you start with. Eventually, you'll switch from one dimension to the other... but I can't stress enough about how well it mantains that Rusty Lake feeling while being transposed to 3D. 

From a game design perspective, I can see the challenges that may have been presented during development. Whatever they've done, it paid off. The cube concept is really cool! And it has many things to do in such a condensed space, at least enough to carry half a game. 

Even though I've talked about how easy puzzles are, I'll say that the concept overcomes this aspect in many way, providing insight to interesting choices design-wise which can and will keep you entertained for its interesting yet brief duration.

For my playthrough I've chosen the butterfly and I've started off in the future. Interesting pick, and I'm satisfied with it! When I'll have the chance, I'll replay through the other perspective. 

[h3]Atmosphere[/h3]
Thank you, Victor Butzelaar! 
Rusty Lake always had amazing, eerie and distinctive piano sections. It's interesting to see that the soundtrack manages to get better at each iteration of this series, and I can't express how well thought it feels and, of course, is. 

I think I've reviewed every Rusty Lake game, if I'm not wrong. I always wonder what they'll come up with, since this is an evolving story, filled with mystery and eerieness. Story-wise, The Past Within is extremely important and, for me, has set up a whole interesting area which I can't wait to explore. 

Of course, the game is very peculiar in some ways. It retains some of that "flash game" feeling, something many players wouldn't really like nowadays, but I think this series evolved just right and it now has (since Roots, as far as I'm concerned) a distinctive character surrounding it. 

[h3]Closing Thoughts[/h3]
Point and click games aren't for everyone, as they could come across as "boring" since there's a lot of stuff to do. 
But I would invite you to invest some time in the Rusty Lake lore and learn about each piece of media that has been presented until now. 

I'm sure you'll find it interesting!

As a fan of the Rusty Lake and Cube Escape series, I just had to get this when it came out. I recommend playing through Rusty Lake: Roots before playing this one, because it helps to set context and helps you really experience the atmosphere and lore in this game. ^^

While it is very convenient to play a co-op game without any form of connection/servers etc, I do feel like it lessened the impact of how you are meant to have influenced each other's rooms -- depending on the responsiveness and speed of your co-player, an effect that was meant to happen after an action on your part may feel slightly delayed, dampening the emotional impact or shared shock responses to an event.

Even so, it was an immensely enjoyable game. The puzzles are easier than those of previous Rusty Lake/Cube Escape games, but engaging enough to require communication and thinking. It was also cleverly designed to encourage replaying it from both perspectives. Overall a super fun time to share with a friend -- especially if they like Rusty Lake games too!

141567367.review: Rusty Lake's The Past Within is a unique co-op escape room game that cleverly divides the gameplay between two players. With one in the Past and the other in the Future, communication is key to solving the puzzles and progressing through the story. The game's eerie atmosphere and unsettling motifs add to its charm, though it may be more appreciated by fans familiar with the Rusty Lake series. The asynchronous puzzle system is ingeniously designed, requiring players to relay information and coordinate their actions. While the game occasionally slows down when waiting for the other player, the overall experience is delightful and enjoyable. The Past Within offers a cozy and immersive co-op adventure that will appeal to escape room enthusiasts and Rusty Lake fans alike.

137982143.review:
[b]"The Past Within" is a small co-op puzzle game that will give you some entertaining time when trying to communicate with your friend, explaining what you see and describing strange patterns. It has a nice combination of 2d and 3d graphics, good pacing, eerie atmosphere, cool music and a weird backstory. For sure puzzles could be more creative and challenging, while online co-op with true interactions between players would make it more immersive. Yet, it's a cool way to spend a couple of hours with a friend.


Manometer: 7/10[/b]


The good
- Cute visuals. It combines cleverly 2d and 3d graphics. Nice design of the interactive objects and especially those mechanical parts of the cubic machines.
- You'll have some fun time when trying to communicating with your friend, explaining him what you see, describing various codes or symbols until you find the solution.
- Puzzles could be more challenging and creative, but they have pretty good pacing. Each puzzle gives you enough clues to guide you seamlessly to the next one. Each player constantly needs to give information to the other one in order to proceed so there are no big gaps that one of you gets bored by doing nothing.
- Simplistic, but cool and mysterious small story that keeps you interested till the end.
- It has a weird, eerie atmosphere with some creepy moments.
- Nice calm music.

The bad
- Puzzles have a few interesting mechanics, but they are pretty easy and not so creative. They're mostly pattern matches, and codes based on descriptions between players. If they describe things well, puzzles' get solved almost instantly. It doesn't require much though or imagination. It doesn't have clever objects combinations.
- It could be so much better with online co-op where the actions of one player affect automatically his mate's room. It would be much more immersive and would eliminate the need of constantly exchanging codes.
- Small duration and no replay value even if you try to change roles with your friend.

137525237.review:
Loved the game, but the price point makes the game a hard pill to swallow.

Don't get me wrong, $6 (or whatever your regional price might be) isn't bad and I've bought worse games for more, but its not REALLY $6, its $12. Sure you can play it with a total stranger but if you plan on playing with a friend you both need to own the game. Theres no real way to play this by yourself. That being said if your buying two copys, one for you and one for a friend, its a must by on sale.

Over-all, I'd recommend it. I've played all the rusty lake games so far in one way or another and each one is just as great as the last. Even the shorter ones like this one is fantastic and while its hard to replay it, it still HAS the ability to replay it. If you plan on doing more of these, it might be worth including a second steam key with purchase or put into practice a similar system as the co-op only It Takes Two.

137378200.review:
A short little co-op experience that mainly involves communication over puzzle solving, some hints at a deeper lore and a great atmosphere make for a great experience that doesn't overstay it's welcome.

The story was quite enjoyable, not in your face and it reminded me of the lovecraft story [spoiler]The Case of Charles Dexter Ward[/spoiler]

The main cons are that the initial room feels quite empty and the graphics aren't quite up to par, this is mostly fixed in the latter parts of the game though, and that the co-op is almost entirely about communication over puzzle solving.

The asymmetric multiplayer doesn't really add to the replayability but there is apparently a second campaign available but I have not played it. In addition due to the way the game is made, interaction is limited to scripted exchanges, instead of the real time experience of other games in the genre. For the same reasons the game does progress quite linearly I feel, there is almost never more than one thing to be doing.

I got it on a sale for half off, at that price point it is a steal but it still feels quite fairly price at 6$. 

I would wholeheartedly recommend it if you have a friend.

The biggest problem is the puzzles. They're just not challenging or particularly clever. They also get quite repetitive once you, for instance, get the idea of putting in a code, they pointlessly make you repeat that 4-5x in one puzzle quest, let alone, coming back to the same puzzle again and again. In some ways, they're more tasks than puzzles. I feel an iteration on this game would be amazing if they thought through some of this stuff a little better, it would make for a fun and fantastic game. It just kind of missed the mark the way it is currently.

126071648.review:
[b]Pro Tip![/b] For anyone who knows they are going to enjoy this game. When you play the first time around, only give as much information to the other person as they need to solve their puzzle. Don't describe everything you see, but don't sandbag the mission. You will be given a chance to play it again, with slightly different puzzles, but from the other perspective. So, the less "extra stuff" you know, the more unique the experience will be the second time around. 

Very few games have accomplished everything The Past Within did, and the Rusty Lake team executed it perfectly.
[list]
    [*]The difficulty is such that I got someone who doesn't play games much to play with me
    [*]You can play from many different platforms
    [*]You don't need to worry about connecting the two devices in any way (how much of a pain can that be these days?)
    [*]It doesn't overstay its welcome. It's about 1.5-2 hours long for 1 play through
    [*]You can play it twice, if you want
    [*]The story is very unique (if you aren't familiar with Rusty Lake)
[/list]

If you want a co-operative experience that isn't crazy challenging, but still fun, with a weird and alluring story, check this out. 

It's kind of like a less stressful, longer and easier version of Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes.

I think this is a suitable Rusty Lake game if you want to introduce the Rusty Lake universe to your friends who have never experienced it before, but for us long time fans, it is one of the weaker Rusty Lake games, I feel like.
Mainly because the puzzles were so straightforward/easy. Instead of figuring things out, you were told by your partner what to do (and vice versa). I also didn't like the timed section because, well, I don't like timed tasks in general, but also because I had to redo it a bunch of times because there was too much of a delay between me and my partner and we just weren't able to communicate fast enough (we were in different countries), which was very annoying.
However, I enjoyed the overall experience anyway! I especially liked the introduction of the 3D world while also retaining the traditional 2D world, and the replayability aspect (will come back to experience The Future and get all of the achievements!). Some parts were also pretty scary, and the art, music, sound design and atmosphere was great, as always! Definitely worth the wait.
Keep up the good work, Rusty Lake, I'm rooting for you!

125160993.review:
I knew about the developers of this game from their previous titles (Cube Escape/Rusty Lake Series), if you're into puzzle solving/click adventures with a deep story, be sure to give this game a go with a friend or one of the developers' previous titles. The puzzles are very creative, and they're not too difficult where you'd be stuck for hours on end, it has a very good skill gap for beginners and advanced players who are familiar with puzzle solving. 

The games have a very cool aesthetic, and The Past Within was just what the series needed, a co-op style game, where you can play with a friend, since all the previous games were singleplayer. Get this game, and get a friend to play it with, and you'll have a fun time. I have next to nothing to critique this game about, but it could just be that I'm a biased person since I loved the other games. 

tl;dr if you like puzzles and cool stories, play the games you won't regret it.

124959471.review:
truly an amazing game, I was a bit concerned when I heard that the game would be co-op but not connected with your partners game directly, as the few games like that that I have played felt "unsmooth" and "jumpy". I am oh so happy to announce that is not the case with The Past Within.
 the experience was completely smooth with no jarring transitions, everything seemed to happen after your partner told you what you were meant to do, even if you looked around it was hard to notice the moment things changed, and the change in perspective from chapter one to two was beautifully done, with the 3D being beautiful and yet somehow keeping the essence of the very stylized 2D.
the paradoxical way that one room is inside the other is strange but delivered very well and the characters are portrayed in a way that feels natural with what we have seen, not introducing much new in the story but still explaining questions that were in my mind for a while and with a couple of puzzles that are still being figured out as of writing is really a show of how committed Rusty Lake is to keeping the point-and-click horror genre alive and innovative

Feels like it should have been a short, mildly amusing browser game but you're going to be paying $12 for two copies of a 70 minute experience that should have been half an hour.

This is definitely not a puzzle game. It's almost literally a copy of "Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes", except without the time limit and framed in the Rusty lake motif where you click on things until something a tad creepy happens.

There's almost zero thinking or interpretation of the information you pass to the other player. You see a time, they adjust a clock to that time. They see 3 sliders set to a position, you set your sliders to the same position. That's it.

Occasionally some cute or creepy effect happens when you do something, your typical Rusty Lake stuff. If you're fine with that being the only upside, then go for it. However I did play this with a big Rusty Lake fan and she thought it was merely okay and all the other games were better.

(you can play it a 2nd time by switching roles with the other person, but you already know every challenge coming up, so it's just going to be seeing two new backgrounds. The only thing that changed between the "Butterfly" and "Bee" setting is scrambling the solutions to the same stuff)

131242152.review:
I hate to say this, but Rusty Lake dropped the ball with this one. I played through all their other titles in the past few weeks, and I can honestly say that (as far as I'm concerned) this is by far the worst one. Now, it's not a *bad* game, but it *is* a bad Rusty Lake game.

Even though the 3D part is a breath of fresh air, the puzzles barely deserve to be called that way. As a bunch of other people already said, they mostly look like this:
Player A: "go there, do this"
Player B: "ok, I got the item, now you do this",

and so on and so forth for an hour or two.

I played through both routes (butterfly and bee), and both timelines, and you really don't gain anything by doing so. If you're on the fence about buying it and want to play the game just for the story, here, I'll save you the money:
[spoiler]Rose Vanderboom and her future self (or her past self, depending on your point of view) work on resurrecting Albert, they succeed, Albert uses the black and the golden cube to merge the timelines. [/spoiler] The past is never dead, it's not even past.

 If you really want to get it, at least wait for a discount. Other Rusty Lake games give you much more bang for your buck.

140088897.review:
A great little co-op game that is pretty economically priced to boot. Definitely worth picking up if you have someone to play along with. Do note, co-op is necessary, it is not an option.

Pros:

1) An interesting, somewhat creepy story. Definitely unique and different.

2) Intuitive controls that are fun to explore. The game expects you to poke around and figure things out with the help of your teammate. You will absolutely have to work in tandem and I loved the experience.

3) Even though this is co-op, you aren't actually connected to each other, meaning that you can even play with someone across the world without having to bother about latency of the server. All you would need would be some communication channel to talk through.

Cons:

1) The game is quite short. I finished it in an hour and a half. You could get a second play-through in by swapping around the characters, but that would still be 3 hours at best. Of course, your time to complete may vary. Personally I do not see this as a significant con, especially since the game is so reasonably priced, but it is something to keep in mind.

1) This is not a puzzle game. Most of the time solution is to look around and find a thing where you need to input the code provided by the partner.
2) Puzzles make no sense. They don't follow any logic. Most of the time the connection between the things that 2 players do is simply ridiculous.
3) Misadvertising: all this Future and Past stuff is non-existent. There are no actions and outcomes that allow you to feel temporal causality, it's like you are sitting in different rooms and communicating.
4) Misadvertising: there's no "plan" to uncover. You simply follow instructions and the goal is laid out from the start.
5) Disconnection from your partner (this is essentially a single-player game, as both of you are not synced) makes you not care about multiplayer aspect.

Overall it's a nice concept (a multiplayer game that doesn't require any connection), but the execution is horrendous. If not for some screamers I'd be deadly bored with the game instead of [b]just bored[/b].

159827050.review:
[h1]The loop is broken. The gap is closed[/h1]

It's the only Rusty Lake game you can play with a friend. It is a co-op game where you can play either in the future or in the past. A network connection is not a must but you need a mean of communication to give each other the hints you find around to proceed the game. The story about Rose who will carry on her father's Albert Vanderboom plan, help her through multiple puzzles with your friend to unravel the mystery. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3172885749

This new experience is exciting, especially with the cooperative puzzles that can be played cross-platforms with your friend. One of the players will play the classic 2d with a creepy atmosphere like how all Rusty lake games plays, and the other will have the 3d mode where he'll have a huge cube with multiple puzzles which can't be solved without a friend's help. There is no in-game chat, you'll have to use either discord or any other communication mean. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3172885161

I always enjoy the game's atmospheric soundtracks, this game was no different, the music fits the creepy atmosphere well. I also liked the concept of this game, which you'll understand by the end. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3172885969

Pros:
+Interesting side of Albert Vanderboom and his daughter Rose.
+Co-op gameplay (Two players must play the game, and is cross-platform, with no need for an internet connection)
+Good soundtracks.
+Variety of puzzles.
+Eeirie atmosphere.
+Steam achievements.

Cons:
-The story could be confusing; you must play the series' other games to understand it.
-No hinting system. Sometimes, you get stuck and don't know what to do next.

Although the game is short, the experience was good and some of the parts were surprising, I highly recommend playing both sides to understand the story more, each side gameplay takes about two hours, in total four hours to beat the game. Some of the achievements are tricky though, you might need a guide to get them all.

154220099.review:
[h1]The past or the future?[/h1]

The Past Within is a co-op game, but with a slightly different twist than a typical co-op game. In the game, we have to uncover the secrets of Albert Vanderboom, a deceased man, and in order to discover them we have to join forces with another player who is in the future or the past (the choice depends on us and our partner). On the other hand, we don't need to connect with the other player to complete further puzzles, but only need text or voice communication to do so.

In general, the game features well-crafted puzzles that require communication with another player to complete. They are often based on the mapping of some patterns. They are not difficult puzzles, but completing each successive one is really satisfying. They are also logical and related to the game's plot. However, over time they can become monotonous.

The graphics of the game are very nice. The game has its own extravagant style, and depending on whether you play in the future or the past, you play in either 2D or 3D mode, which is intuitive and I didn't encounter any bugs in either mode.

Sound-wise it is also very good, we have dubbing and a pleasant soundtrack, on top of that the ambient sounds are equally good.

We can go through the game from two perspectives and, on top of that, by choosing one of the insects, which gives a total of four possible passages of the game, although they are not too different from each other. However, the choice of insects is not very important, it slightly changes some of the puzzles. Therefore, I recommend going through the game twice: in the future and in the past.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

The Past Within is a really good game. It is not a game that is difficult, the subsequent puzzles were not a difficulty for me and my friend, but we had fun playing it, which is what it is all about. Plus the lack of bugs, a good atmosphere and the evening passed quickly and pleasantly.
[b]
✔️Specific, nice graphics
✔️The game is even atmospheric
✔️The sound design is really good

✔️❌The puzzles may be too simple for some

❌The game is very short

[i]Time of completion:  2-3 hours[/i]

[b][u]Rating: 6/10[/u][/b]

157800924.review:
[i] My Experience [/i]

Although [b]The Past Within[/b] didn't end up making my top 10 for 2022, it was definitely a contender. I'm always a sucker for asymmetric co-op, and [b]The Past Within[/b] shares the cool design of [b]Tick Tock: A Tale for Two[/b] in that two players can play together without actually being connected online. I played the "Past" side, while my co-op partner played the "Future." I'm unsure what difference it ends up making, but we selected the bee instead of the butterfly at the beginning of the game.

I loved the illustrated characters, the items, and the environments in the game, as well as the auditory and visual effects that occur at key shocking moments. The whole thing feels like a creepy voodoo ritual, which does seem to jive with the universe of [b]Rusty Lake[/b] from my understanding (I haven't played any other [b]Rusty Lake[/b] games). Solving this macabre puzzle box was really unlike anything I've done in a game before, and I had a lovely time doing so.

Another thing I came to appreciate more while watching the "Let's Play" is the way that objects and actions in the past correspond to those in the future, as certain streamers were able to bounce between the perspective of the Past and Future player. At one point, the player in the future starts playing some beat-heavy music. In response, the furniture within the room of the player in the past begins inexplicably (from your perspective) bumping and shaking around (which helps unlock a way forward).

In general, the puzzles are quite well-designed in the game. They're intuitive without being easy, and I felt a sense of satisfaction at each critical story juncture. The only type of player I wouldn't recommend this game to would be a solo gamer since it's inherently a cooperative experience. However, if you have a bud to take on the ride, you should take it. It's also relatively cheap and short, so it's easy to fit in if you have a lot going on.
